Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JustBrandon Hello again, you may recall me posting in january that my dad's psa had risen to 0.13 and i had expressed concern over it. Well they did a re test today and the doctorbsaid "Mr Otinger, i Have good news, your PSA has fallen to <0.1, which is essentially ZERO. The ultrasensative assay we use can sometimes glitch and overestimate values, and that is what happened with your January test. You are good to go, and continue to enjoy being free of prostate cancer. ☺☺☺☺ BIG sigh of relief there. So i can happily say he is still in "Club Zero" Perhaps I'm missing something...have all these PSAs been done using the same tests? While the 0.13 may have been erroneous, <0.1 is nowhere as near zero as << 0.04 as in the earlier tests. Obviously, something to keep an eye on!

The possibility of salvage radiation was mentioned, however this would hinge on PSA #, which of course have not been done yet. So I see it somewhat alarming (to me being so close to in your shoes) that you are already considering radiation even before your first PSA result. Are you and your doc being too aggressive, or is my uro being too conservative and missing something?

Seems a bit premature to consider a biopsy at this point. They aren't completely risk free, can be hit and miss, and depending on your insurance, not free. (My first one cost me $1500 out of pocket) Just relax and continue to keep an eye on things. Welcome to the forum - hopefully your partner will not join the group!

Posts.Title: What is your choice

Posts.Content: Actually, 30% in the above case would be 0.003 ng/ml - still basically undetectable. I had never had free PSA analyzed in my case, so I was wondering what it was about and after reading a little bit last night I see having a low % free PSA may be an indication of cancer. Couldn't find an explanation why. Intuitively I would think if you had a tumor actively secreting PSA at a higher level then the normal prostate tissue would that it would likely lead to higher free PSA %, but I guess it must become protein bound more quickly then normal PSA?

Posts.Title: Decision time approaching

Posts.Content: 10 days out from surgery (stiil with catheter) and have been doing pretty well. But this morning it seems like after switching to my leg bag and going out for a short walk, I was having some initial discomfort down there, probably just with the placement of the catheter tube (its always hit or miss on when the catheter will be not noticeable or not). Returned to the car for a bit, then joined my friends at the coffee shop, While sitting, I still had some issue with getting perfectly comfortable, and by the time I returned home I had the feeling of the urge to pee. Entering the bathroom and seeing the toilet even made it feel more urgent, kind of like the "old days" - I just wanted to drop my pants and let go, but also had the urge to squeeze and hold back.. Is this normal? Could it be a "side effect" of having the catheter in longer then 7 days, and things are trying to return to normal? And is this an indication of worst things to come? ( I recall in my other thread of someone who had a lot of discomfort on days 12-14 before his catheter was removed) Now that i've been lounging on my bed for the last 30 min, this discomfort is gone.
Posts.Title: urge to pee?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by toloh For me, the sensations of the urge to urinate did not return until about 6 weeks after the cath was removed. Other than leaking around the catheter, I had no physical problems with it. funny you should mention "leaking around the catheter".....I was just logging on to ask that question! Just a short while ago as I was getting ready to take a shower, that urge to pee came back and for a few moments I did not fight to see what would happen and I am pretty sure that I began passing a dribble of urine at my tip around the outside of the catheter. Naively, I would guess that could be possible if somehow urine slipped around the catheter inside the bladder, could it escape down the inside of ureter on the outside of the catheter?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by h60av8er My question is, what should I do, within my control, to make sure the test is as accurate as possible? Anything I should or should not eat, drink, take or do leading up to the test? Thank you. To answer your question- it is what it is. Obviously you don't want to do anything to mask or attempt to manipulate your psa level- the numbers are what they are and you need to know them! On further pondering, if you are really asking should you avoid doing something that could increase your psa, then yes- as stated above "your prostate has left the building" and can no longer be influenced by diet, infection, exercise, etc. So don't worry. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Acronyms

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by shu246 Hey, Prato - I've been away a long time too, but is not the standard <0.1? My understanding was the test equipment may register some number less than 0.1 mg/nl, but anything that low is within the jiggle tolerance of the equipment and is therefore not really differentiable from zero. It is, within the capability limits of the equipment, "not detectable." Alla you numbers is below that. Nicht var? - shu Indeed, I've seen some use >0.2 as the cutoff for biochemical recurrence or failure. Moreover at 0.01 you are the limits of detection anyway, depending upon the brand of the test and equipment calibration. So, 0.02 really is insignificant if the test has a threshold of 0.015. So hopefully all will be good!

My understanding was the test equipment may register some number less than 0.1 mg/nl, but anything that low is within the jiggle tolerance of the equipment and is therefore not really differentiable from zero. It is, within the capability limits of the equipment, "not detectable." Alla you numbers is below that. Nicht var? - shu Indeed, I've seen some use >0.2 as the cutoff for biochemical recurrence or failure. Moreover at 0.01 you are the limits of detection anyway, depending upon the brand of the test and equipment calibration. So, 0.02 really is insignificant if the test has a threshold of 0.015. So hopefully all will be good!

Posts.Title: Wife in full remission

Posts.Content: Greetings...new here! I'm home recovery from da Vinci surgery 5 days ago. Feeling pretty good, last hydrocodone Saturday, and not even any ibubrofens today. Even getting use to catheter however.... Called my urologist office today to check to see when my post op appointment was scheduled for, figuring this Thursday (usual office day for him). Needless to say I was FLOORED when I was told my appt was Thursday.... 3/30!!! 22 DAYS with a bag strapped to my leg?? This seems highly unusual and pretty sure he said preop it would be 7-10 days if tests okay. Surgery and prostate removal went real well I was told, and indeed have absolutely no discomfort down there. Maybe its a scheduling mistake? Any one had a catheter in longer then 2 weeks? Thanks! Edit: And did most have a cystogram prior to catheter removal?

Posts.Title: Three Days Post-Op

Posts.Content: Hi guys, its been awhile. Had my 2 year checkup last week (my does time go quickly) and happy to report PSA was 0.00 - certainly more pleasing then the 0.01 which was 6 months ago! Overall, not much change in the last year. Still have the occasional (monthly) seepage - which is never more then a couple drops, or just the feeling that I might have a whoopsy that doesn't even make it to my underwear. One time moving around on a barstool caused it, but usually its just in the morning on a relatively empty bladder, and probably because of coffee drinking. So overall, very pleased with that. As far as erections go, not too bad. Won't ever be the way it was presurgery, but certainly well enough to keep me interested on a daily basis. The days of spontaneous "pitching a tent" in the morning are gone, but have noticed in the last year an occassional swelling in the morning. One thing I did note only a few weeks back was a little bit of curvature that I hadn't notice before, and my doc said that could be some mild Peyronie's happening. As long as it didn't interfere with function or was painful, I should not worry about it. So very pleased so far on the RALP outcome. Hope all is well with the rest of you!
